title: Return and Rebuilding

segments.audio_script: This is lesson twenty-three. You are studying return and rebuilding. Lesson twenty-two examined prophetic hope.
Exiled Israel returns to Jerusalem. Rebuilding begins under Persian permission. The temple is reconstructed. Covenant worship resumes. The return is partial restoration.
Post-exilic period involves rebuilding community and worship. Jerusalem walls are rebuilt. Torah is read publicly. Covenant becomes centered on law and community identity.
Key themes: return fulfills prophetic promise. Rebuilding restores covenant worship. Community reforms emerge around Torah. Covenant is renewed through restored institutions.
What do returned exiles rebuild in Jerusalem?
This completes lesson twenty-three. You studied return and rebuilding. Final lesson examines waiting and messianic expectation.

vocabulary.definition: Historical era following return from Babylonian exile marked by rebuilding and Torah-centered community
Rebuilt temple following return from exile serving as center of post-exilic worship

study_notes: Post-exilic period marks transition in covenant structure. Torah becomes central to Jewish identity and practice.
